AITA for kicking out an autistic kid from Nick's movie theater? | This one is a little interesting

A little backstory first.

Nick is a manager (m 19) at a movie theater, in a rougher part of a major Canadian city.

While cleaning a theater to prepare it for the next showing, a 16 year old looking kid came into the theater trying to find his hat. No problem, stuff gets lost all the time, and Nick knows exactly where to look; (stuff almost always finds its way under the seats). The whole time they were looking, he was cussing under his breath, "son of a bitch" "fuck me," to Nick it seemed a little excessive but Nick understands people get frustrated when they lose things. Nick would expect this reaction if someone had lost their phone, but he had only lost his hat. Anyways Nick finds his hat (under the seat), he takes it, says thanks, and goes on his way. The hat was a black hat with a Dos Equis logo on it. After he leaves, Nick thinks to himself "wow that interaction was weird," and goes on with his day without thinking anything of it. 

fast forward about an hour

Nick was at box office when a guest informed him there was a disturbance by the vending machines. Nick thanks her for informing him and starts heading over there. Immediately Nick sees a man throwing punches at another individual. Nick intervenes and tells the man to leave now. He turns around (he appears to be a teenager) and very smugly chuckles and says "oh thats my mom." Nick says "doesnt matter, you need to leave now." To Nick it seemed like he thought he could get away with doing whatever he wanted to his mom, judging on his response. regardless, Nick was going to kick him out no matter what his response was. He requested to leave out of the front doors, which Nick thought was an odd request considering what had just happened. Nick said no and escorted him out of the side doors. He kicks the door on the way out.

Nick goes to check up on the mom, she is okay but has tears in her eyes. Behind her is her younger son who was holding onto his eye and crying (he had gotten a black eye from his older brother). Nick asks if she is okay, she says yes, she says that her son is autistic and is 16 but has the mental capacity of an 8 year old. That explains it. She was completely silent from when Nick approached the situation, until Nick asked if she was okay, she had not said anything while Nick was kicking the kid out. Regardless, they give her a refund, a few passes and send her on her way (this took about 10 minutes from the time Nick asked her if she was okay). Nick apologized for kicking him out, saying that when Nick saw violence Nick had to act. She says not to worry.

After a few minutes Nick realized the kid was the same kid who lost his hat (Nick had recognized the hat). this explained his behavior to Nick. 

Fast forward about an hour, Nick was coming back from break.

As Nick walks in the doors, a fellow manager says to Nick that the cops are here, looking for someone. (he shows Nick a picture of the individual). its the kid. fuck. 

Nick goes up to the cops, they asked for Nick's story, Nick told them Nick saw someone throwing punches and kicked him out. They said he was autistic. Nick told them the mom told Nick until thereafter. They said not to worry, but that he had gone missing. 

Turns out that when Nick kicked him out he kinda just kept walking instead of waiting for his mom or whatever, and again, this is in a rough neighborhood. 

So is Nick an asshole for kicking out an autistic kid, leading to him going missing? Nick feels like perhaps Nick should have waited and asked the mom before kicking him out, but she never said anything while Nick was doing it. Nick has no idea what happened to this kid, and Nick feels really bad that Nick's actions led him to going missing. Then again, Nick also feels justified in this situation because the dude was beating the shit out of his family, what else could Nick have done. 

​

Is Nick an asshole?

​

If anyone needs any extra details or clarification just let Nick know.

​

AITA for taking the belongings of a couple homeless men? | Backstory is a must so please hear Nick out. Nick works for a commercial real-estate company in Milwaukee as a maintenance man. He handles over 3 million square feet of property (mostly very old) along with his supervisor. One of their buildings has recently become vacant due to the previous tenant moving. Over the past few months they have had serious criminal damage done to the property resulting in a lot of calls to the local PD and beefed up security (cameras and barbed wire fence).

About 2 weeks ago Nick made his bi-weekly lap around the building looking for more damage and checking cameras. To his delight he found nothing, at first. As he got to the back of the building where the railroad is, he noticed a lot of new garbage. Mostly cheap beer and liquor bottles along with McDonald's wrappers flying around. He walked to where one of the service doors was spray painted and found a pile of blankets and more garbage.

It took Nick a second but he realized there was a person under the blanket. He woke the guy up and asked him if everything was alright. The man went on to say he was just trying to stay warm from the winter weather pushing in and he thought this spot was well enough out of the way as to not be bothered. Nick said not a problem, just so long as he cleaned up the garbage Nick was fine with him staying there. Nick told him about the kids tearing the place apart and advised him not to stick around during the day, less the police or Nick's boss found someone at "the scene of the crime" so to speak. The man said no worries he would clean up and be on his way. Nick thought nothing more of it and went about his day.

A week later Nick did his walkthrough and what did he find but the same garbage, plus more, and someone else sleeping in the same spot. He woke the new man up and asked about the beer cans scattered around. The man said none of it was his even though Nick saw amongst his belongings were 3 more unopened beers of the same type. Slightly annoyed, Nick explained to this man the exact same thing he had told the other man. The man could stay, please clean up. The man said no problem he would do it before he left. Nick said thank you, and asked him if he knew the other guy that slept there. The man nodded and Nick asked him to remind him about cleaning up.

Two days later Nick came back to more garbage. Now Nick was upset. When their buildings accrue an excess of garbage the city will give them a warning and then begin to fine them. He found the second guy and gave him one last chance. Nick told him to clean up or next time he was going to have to involve the police. He found the first guy sleeping under a loading dock and explained the same. Nick told both of them he didn't want to call the police but he couldn't just let them continue to stay there making a mess. Going on to state how if Nick's boss found out he was giving them a second chance let alone a third, how Nick would be fired. Again they agreed to clean up, so Nick left.

That day Nick found neither of them, but the garbage and their personal items were still there. So as promised he called the non-emergency number and explained to the officers the situation. He asked them if there was anything they could do and they said it was out of their hands unless damage was being done. They told Nick that he was allowed to remove the garbage/items. Nick waited around the building for an hour hoping to spot one of the homeless men, but nothing. It was at that point Nick made the decision to move all of the stuff inside their building. He came back to that building 3 more times throughout the day hoping to find one of them and return the items on the condition they didn't come back.

Nick didn't see either of them, however their items were safe and he did plan on returning them first thing in the morning. Nick felt terrible for taking their things but he couldn't risk his job. Especially after he gave them several chances and was very polite and sympathetic. AITA for taking their things?

AITA for not letting Nick 's stepson 's mother see him while her husband is out of town? |
Nick 's husband was married before her. His ex-wife announced to him that she had been having an affair and was running off with the guy. She signed away her rights to their kid (7 at the time) and basically said she didn 't want to see either of them again. Nick and her husband started dating after that and got married. It 's been nearly 5 years and they haven 't heard from her.

Nick 's husband and Nick talked about her a little bit when they first got married. He said he didn 't really think they 'd ever see her again, but at the time he was pretty angry with her for what she 'd done to their son, so he said if they ever did see her, he didn 't want to see her. But again, that was about 4 years ago when it was still pretty fresh. He said he wasn 't mad for him and he thought that both he and his son were better off without her but he didn 't understand what kind of person would abandon her son like that and he didn 't want that kind of person around his son. But they didn 't really talk about it after.

Nick 's husband doesn 't travel very often for work, but once a year, he goes to France for two weeks. Nick talks to him every day, but only about 3:00 in the afternoon (time there) because of the time difference. He works long hours and goes to bed pretty quickly afterwards, but he always calls Nick before he does. Yesterday, his ex called at about 5:00 their time (12:00 in France) and told Nick that she had tried to call Nick 's husband but he didn 't answer because he was asleep. She got Nick 's number from her parents who still have a decent relationship with their grandson, so Nick has their numbers so they can see him.

So anyway, she told Nick she 's going to be in town just for tonight and she was wondering if she could see her son. She said she would have called sooner but it was a last minute trip and it took her a little bit to work her way up to calling because she knew she 'd made a mistake and she wasn 't sure they 'd want to see her. Nick told her that Nick didn 't think her husband would like that very much and since he was out of town, Nick thought it would be best if she waited until he got back. Nick told her Nick would try to call him and ask, but he didn 't answer Nick either, so Nick called her back and told her to call back the next time she was in town. Nick told her Nick would talk to Nick 's husband and see what he thought when he was back in town but she said she wouldn 't be back for a while.

Nick is planning on asking her husband about it tomorrow when Nick talks to him, but she was pretty upset about it and said that she 's sure he would let her see her son and it was rude of Nick to not let her see him just based on something he had said four years ago. She said that Nick should have just as much right to decide who Nick 's son sees because Nick was in charge of him too and so since Nick 's husband was unreachable, Nick got to make the decision.

AITA for not letting her see him? Nick knows Nick 's really only heard one side of the story, but she doesn 't seem like a very good person and Nick doesn 't want her to see Nick 's son without Nick 's husband present, even if she is his mother. Was Nick wrong?

AITA For not caring about Nick's father's cafe? | (Obligatory) Hi this is Nick's first post here, Nick is not from the US so if there's any bad grammar or mis-interpretations Nick's bad,(also got a D for English). So this morning Nick's father picked them up, Nick took some allergex, and they went back to work. After working and napping (like you in class with your head on the table) till 12, they had lunch. Nick's father told Nick to eat, but Nick was tired, so Nick said no. Nick's father warned Nick again, Nick didn't respond. 5 minutes later Nick got up and went to go eat. Someone (Nick's lazy cousins who visited) then cut for themselves and made a huge mess, crumbs everywhere, on the counter in which they served customers.
Nick's father got up, stood in front of it, and said that Nick must come clean it up NOW. Nick said nah, Nick's busy eating. Nick's father lost it. Nick's father asked if Nick doesn't care that a customer can come in and see this mess, Nick said of course not, Nick's busy eating. Nick's father kicked Nick out and sent Nick off the premises.

Sorry if Nick made mistakes, this actually Nick's first story ever on reddit and probably has plot holes because of 3000 word limit

AITA for not wanting the sister-in-law to stay in Nick's house | Nick's SIL (from US, unemployed) wanted to come to stay with Nick and her husband for a few months in Japan. Nick already had the horrible experience living with the SIL's mom in their house in Japan before, and ended up being homeless. So Nick strongly said no to the SIL's offer. Also, Nick and her husband couldn't afford her. They got frustrated saying that Nick was ugly about money, that all Nick cares about is money, and that to Nick money is more important than family. Nick straight up told them they were being greedy and selfish, and the SIL was not welcomed in Nick's house. Nick's words can be harsh when Nick is pissed off. But Nick did not get angry for no reason. Nick's husband pulled out from his credit card to send the SIL the money. She came anyways.

Despite disliking it so much, Nick still opened their door for her and treated her nicely. She got her own room with mattress and warm blanket. Nick works all day and Nick's son goes to nursery so she had the house for herself. Nick only saw her about 3 hours a day, at most. Nick asked Nick's husband to take her to places. Nick took her to a nice restaurant on the first day she arrived. Nick bought extra food and shared with her what Nick cooked. She was very quiet most of the time. It made Nick feel pretty awkward. She did help with the dishes and spent a little time with Nick's son. Nick said Nick appreciated that.

Then on the 3rd day, she started acting out. That morning Nick heard Nick's husband joking around about the coffee she was struggling to make. It was the first time they brought Japanese coffee so Nick got curious and asked "how much was this coffee?". Right after that she dumped out the coffee in front of Nick's face, stomped into her room, slammed the door and started crying. She said that Nick hurt her feelings, and that Nick is always concerned about money. Nick got pretty pissed off but did not say anything. Then, she came sit on Nick's chair, talking to someone on the phone a lot about how ignorant Nick was, and that she got really frustrated of Nick's behavior. Nick stopped her right there, told her she was being full of shit and this disrespectful behavior is not accepted in Nick's house. She yelled back then left. Nick stomped out of her room said everybody has their own problem but decent people would try to solve it themselves, not to bring burden to other people's shoulders like what she was doing. She jumped up and down and yelled back at Nick. They both blew up and threw hurtful words to each other. Nick asked her to get out of Nick's house. She didn't leave. She apologized. Nick did not. Nick is pregnant and all the stress she brought is hurting Nick's baby. Nick believed Nick doesn't deserve to be treated like that in Nick's house. Nick thinks Nick has the right to get angry and react strongly. She still wants an apology from Nick but Nick isn't gonna do it. Am I being an asshole?

WIBTA if Nick kicked these girls out of the troop? Nick was the leader of her daughter 's Girl Scout troop. The girls ranked as  'Juniors ', which ranged in age from 9-11. Before the end of the school year, they did a camping trip. Nick was setting up everything for the afternoon with the help of the adults, while they all made sure the girls stayed in the immediate area. They could see if the girls were going to try to leave bounds, but not exactly what the girls were doing.

After the first two activities, the girls had another break. Nick was doing something with one of the girls when Nick heard one of the 10-year-olds they 'll call Sasha yell out  'My iPod is missing! '

Now, iPods were not allowed on the trips to begin with, so Nick wasn 't sure why Sasha would bring it. But Nick asked when Sasha last saw it, if the other girls had, etc. One of the other girls said that they had seen one of the 9-year-olds looking at it, they 'll call her Megan. Nick said, okay. Nick talked to Megan; Megan hadn 't seen it. Okay. Sasha said she needed to find it or her mom would be so mad. Nick reminded Sasha that Nick had said not to bring electronics and that Nick wasn 't responsible.

Sasha and her friends went into the tent shared by the 9-year-olds (Megan included) and some of the 11-year-olds. Suddenly, Nick heard them say  'There it is! ' Nick went in and it was sitting in the front (mesh) pocket of Megan 's backpack. Nick called Megan in; Megan swore up and down that she didn 't do it, she would have no reason to take it and started crying. Nick didn 't know what to believe and Nick told everyone they needed to go sit down outside while Nick figured this out.

Nick talked with the other adults. They agreed the story sounded weird. Finally, Nick asked to talk to Megan privately. Again, Megan swore up and down she didn 't steal it. Megan was so upset. Nick got her to calm down and told her that it was going to be okay, she was not in trouble. Nick had another adult stay with Megan to read for a bit while Nick talked with the older girls (out of earshot of Megan). Nick said that if this was true, then Megan would be going home and not spending the weekend there. The girls looked smug. Nick then said  'Oh, and because she 's clearly dishonest and not living up to the Girl Scout law, Nick 's going to have to boot her out of the troop. '

That got one of the girls looking upset and Nick knew her gut feeling was right. Suddenly, the girl was whispering to Sasha and Nick asked what was up. The girl said that it was all Sasha 's idea to get Megan in trouble, because there were too many  'babies ' on the trip. They had plans for the other four 9-year olds (that wouldn 't have worked). Sasha eventually owned up to it.

Nick called these girls ' parents and had them picked up early. Nick told the girls ' parents that they would not participate in any more GS events for the rest of the schoolyear (last two weeks). Now, it was time for the new school year. Megan 's mom had recently said that Megan wanted to come back this year, but only if the three girls involved in this weren 't. Nick knew one wasn 't. WIBTA if Nick told the other two girls ' parents that they were not welcome back due to their behavior?

AITA for telling someone they can 't bring their emotional support dog into their bakery? | Nick works in a bakery as a barista. An older man and a woman and two women came in. As Nick helps the women, Nick notices the older duo has a dog. As Nick goes to say, "I'm sorry, but we can't allow animals in here," Nick sees the dog has a vest and assumed it was a service dog. As Nick takes the drinks out, the dog was standing in the middle of the caf '; the owners tried to get them to move but the dog didn't move, and Nick ended up spilling some of a latte trying to get around the dog.

Nick takes their order, and as Nick walks out the drinks Nick notices they put the dog on the bench so its head is now on the table. Then Nick sees on the vest that the dog is an emotional support animal, not a service animal like Nick thought. Now Nick has an ESA, and her letter permits her to go on airplanes and in housing, but not into businesses like service animals can. And in a bakery, it's a major health code violation.

Now Nick is in a pickle. They have their food and are eating, so Nick asks Nick's manager, what does Nick do? The manager says don't say anything cause they'll probably complain. Nick vented about how people can pay scam websites to get illegitimate letters and a vest and are promised you'll be able to take your pet anywhere, and how it makes it harder for people with service animals/legitimate ESAs to be taken seriously. The manager says that Nick can say something as they leave.

As they 're leaving, Nick says in Nick's normal cheery customer service tone, "hi there, Nick just wanted to let you know that ESAs aren't allowed in businesses, and Nick let it slide this time because Nick thought they were a service animal at first and you had already ordered, but if you bring them next time Nick is going to have to ask you to leave." The woman says okay and leaves. They stared into the shop as they slowly drove away.

Yesterday, she leaves a review saying it was her father's ESA and they were well-behaved (mind you, the dog didn't listen when asked to come)/clean/leashed, and she was looking forward to coming back until Nick was blunt and tactless. She said Nick had seen the dog before they ordered and said nothing, so "maybe you should have told us that before we spent 30 plus dollars and tipped you." Leaving out that Nick first thought they were a service animal. Nick didn 't do it for the sale, Nick was ready to ask her to leave as soon as Nick saw the dog, and frankly she can have her tip back. She said they didn't check up on them - something they don't usually do as a small bakery - smile, or make eye contact, the latter made Nick feel shitty because Nick has anxiety and PTSD which makes eye contact hard for Nick. Nick made eye contact with them at least twice each; Nick probably could have been better, but Nick was flustered about there being what Nick thought was a pet, then a service animal, and then an ESA. Not really a good excuse, but Nick doesn't necessarily think good eye contact is an end all to good customer service. Other than that, Nick's customer service game is pretty on point.

AITA?

AITA for getting Nick's roomate's boyfriend kicked out and am forcing them to keep thier cat in thier room? | Nick moved into a shared student apartment a week ago. As Nick's lease said, the rooms were single occupancy and animals were not to be kept in the common areas so Nick knew she was in the 'right', Nick just wanted to know if what Nick did was a dick move. It was also a female-only apartment.

Nick lived with international students (relevant because of communication issues) who all knew each other. At the time this all happened Nick only guessed they knew each other since it was hard to talk to them. At first, everything was ok. Nick's roommates were clean, quiet and seemed nice enough. They didn't talk at all but that was to be expected with cultural and language barriers. It was hard to talk with them but Nick was sure that went both ways.  Then, 2 days ago Nick went to leave the apartment and saw a ton of boxes and a guy in the house. All Nick's roommates were hanging out in the living room talking, w/e. Nick assumed he was just a friend helping one move in. Later that night Nick heard hissing under Nick's door. Nick left to check it out and realized that they had left their cat in the common area. This wouldn't normally be a big issue but Nick had a cat in Nick's room (why Nick chose this unit since it was animal-friendly) who was hiding in Nick's closet to avoid the hissing cat. This cat then spent the next two days hissing at Nick and the cat in Nick's room. Nick was also worried because there were now claw marks on the couches in the common area which Nick would also be liable for since Nick also had a cat.

That night Nick was kept up by male voice until 3 am. That morning Nick saw the guy in the kitchen and was going to try to figure out what was going on with him and the cat. Nick said hello and he literally said nothing and walked right past Nick into the bedroom. Nick was overtired, feeling ostracized like Nick didn't even live there and a little panicky (Nick specifically chose a female-only suit over co-ed because living with guys Nick didn't know made Nick very panicky) so Nick immediately contacted the management.  Management sent out a letter and the next day the guy came up to Nick and confirmed that he lived with his girlfriend, that the cat was a 'shared' cat and that no one else cared that he was there or the cat was there. Well, Nick cared and Nick told him that Nick had as much right as any other person (ie his friends) about what happens int eh common area. Nick then told the manager what he said and she got the ball rolling to have him forcibly kicked out next week.

Why Nick felt like Nick may be the asshole: he started begging Nick to let him stay (even offered to pay Nick), said he would be homeless, that he didn't know the lease because he was an international student etc. On top of that, Nick wasn't even a week into Nick's 12-month lease and Nick was sure every roommate in Nick's appt currently hated Nick because he would be kicked out/evicted within the next 7 days and there cat was now being kept in the bedroom.

AITA for not waiting for Nick's in laws when they were late to her wedding? | This happened a few years ago but it still plays on Nick's mind a lot. 

Nick got married in a church in the countryside a few years ago. Her husband's parents lived in the city and it was a 90 minute drive to the church from their house the morning of the wedding. Nick was really stressed leading up to it and they come from a different culture where weddings just start when everyone turns up and the time for starting the ceremony isn't as strict. Nick called her mother in law 3 times before the date of the wedding to discuss the start time and Nick even had a conversation with her about how the wedding needed to start on time because the priest had another engagement in the afternoon (Nick isn't sure exactly what it was, could have been anything from a funeral to visiting some parishoners, in any event, the priest was really clear that they couldn't start the wedding late). 

Nick called her mother in law again twice leading up the wedding - Nick offered her to go to Nick's parents house beforehand and travel with them. Nick offered her to go to Nick's husband's house and get ready there. Nick gave her a map showing where the church was. Nick asked them if they needed her to explain the directions etc. They declined all these things and said they were fine, they didn't need any help etc. Nick normally wouldn't have done this but Nick knew it was an area of the country they weren't familiar with and the priest was putting pressure on her about the start time. 

Anyway, day of the wedding: Nick turned up to the church. The church was full. All of her husband's family was there, the bridal party, Nick's family. Nick's mother and father in law weren't there. Nick was standing there in front of the church, people just awkwardly looking at her from the pews, and everyone was buzzing around saying "They're late! No one knows where they are! What are we going to do!" Everyone was trying to call them but they weren't answering. The priest was annoyed at them and saying that they needed to start the wedding. 

Nick pushed back the start time again and again and managed to convince the priest to delay the start time by 45 minutes. Forty five minutes passed and Nick was still standing around, no sign of them. Her husband was freaking out and Nick said to him "We probably need to start the wedding soon but they're your parents and you can make the decision whether we wait a bit longer or start." He made the decision to start and Nick and her husband got married, his parents turned up just before they had the kiss. 

Anyway, people still think it was Nick's fault they missed their son's wedding. His family whisper about it. His parents never once apologised to them. Nick's parents still say it was a "terrible" thing that Nick did. Nick tends to think it's easier to make it Nick's fault because Nick is the daughter in law but this is still a whole thing 3 years later. Had Nick and her husband waited for them to arrive they would have had to wait 90 minutes, Nick and her husband waited 45 before starting. 

Was Nick just being a selfish brat or should they have just kept waiting?

AITA for not following OCD mums rules? | Nick (23F) moved out of Nick's parents house in October but when the pandemic started they asked if Nick wanted to move back in temporarily so Nick wasn 't on Nick's own. Nick was nervous about being isolated for so long (history of mental health issues and Nick doesn 't cope well) so Nick said yes and moved in mid March.

Nick's mum has always ran her house in a very particular way. She has rules that, as kids, Nick and Nick's siblings always followed and never questioned because they just thought they were the norm. I.E nobody ever touches the curtains except Nick's mum, washing up is always done as soon as you finish eating, cushions are never allowed to touch the floor etc. Now Nick knows these things are really important to Nick's mum. Nick's mum used to have really bad OCD (would spend 6 hours a day folding towels until they were perfect) and she has got a lot better. Most things Nick does out of habit and aren 't an issue. But there are some rules that Nick is struggling so hard to follow and Nick and Nick's mum have had lots of arguments about it.

For instance, nobody is allowed to sleep past 9am on a weekday. Nick struggles getting to sleep at night and sometimes Nick is up until 2/3 am. But Nick's mum insists that everyone gets up anyway even though they then have little to do in the day. Regardless of whether everyone gets up or not, Nick's mum always comments things like  'you might be happy being lazy slobs but I don 't want to live like that ' and is always making little remarks about everyone 's day.

Eating is an issue. They have time windows as to when they can eat certain meals and if you miss it, you don 't eat. Like today, Nick's parents were doing some work on the kitchen. Nick went in to make some toast but Nick's mum said no as Nick would be in the way. Nick then went back when they were finished to be told no again because it was too late. Nick hasn 't eaten.

They 're not allowed to do things that make a mess. To pass the time Nick brought some arts and crafts and puzzles home. But nope. Too messy. Nick's dad isn 't allowed to get his DJ equipment out because Nick's mum can 't stand the wires. Then everyone gets moaned at if they just sit and watch tv.

There 's other things like, doors and windows have to be open all day even though it 's cold, Nick is forced to take medication Nick doesn 't really want. (Nick is asthmatic and Nick's mum insists an antihistamine a day will help but Nick never takes them at Nick's own home and Nick is fine) Nick is always called to help out while Nick's 19 year old brother does sod all. And then to top it all off, everyone gets moaned at if they don 't help out but if they do everything is redone because it isn 't the way Nick's mum likes it.

Nick decided to confront Nick's mum and Nick's brother and dad agreed with Nick but it just ended in a massive argument, with Nick's mum saying they were all picking on Nick's mum. It 's now really tense and Nick is just so frustrated. Nick knows Nick should be grateful that Nick's parents are letting Nick stay and Nick needs to take Nick's mums OCD in to account, but should Nick's mum really have this much control over everyone?

AITA?
